description: Writing style rules for Renewal Weekly newsletter content

voice.summary: A smart friend who reads medical journals. Hopeful but never naive, accessible but never dumbed down.

contrastSetup.description: Long context followed by short punchy impact
contrastSetup.pattern: [X million] Americans with [condition], the prognosis has always been the same: [limitation]. That changed this week.
contrastSetup.example: For 20 million Americans with age-related macular degeneration, the prognosis has always been the same: We can slow it down, but we can't bring back what you've lost. That changed this week.

heresWhat.description: Break down complex info with clear labels
heresWhat.example: **Here's what happened:** Patients gained the ability to read 21 additional letters on an eye chart.

relatableTranslation.description: Follow technical info with real-world meaning
relatableTranslation.example: 21 additional letters on an eye chart. For context, that's the difference between needing help crossing the street and reading a restaurant menu.

honestCaveat.example: **The catch:** Results varied based on how cells were delivered. There's no standardized protocol yet.

contrarianOpening.pattern: The [industry] wants you to believe [common belief]. [Source] disagrees.
contrarianOpening.example: The supplement aisle wants you to believe you need pills for everything. Harvard disagrees.

rules: Use {{LINK:display text|url}} for links embedded naturally in sentences
Use **bold** for section labels: **Here's what happened:** **The catch:**
Use em dashes (—) for asides, not parentheses

linkStyle.rule: Embed links in natural reading flow, link meaningful words
linkStyle.good: Researchers at the {{LINK:University of Michigan|url}} published results...

wordsToAvoid: at the end of the day

trustTest.description: Before publishing any content, ask these 5 questions
questions: Would I send this to my parent with arthritis? (Is it clear and respectful?)
Would a doctor cringe? (Is it accurate without overpromising?)
Would a skeptic roll their eyes? (Is it honest about limitations?)
Would a scanner get value? (Can someone skim and learn something?)
Would I click the links? (Are they genuinely useful?)
